actors.name: Application Users
actors.description: Application users refer to individuals with different roles and responsibilities within an enterprise, such as Sustainability Managers, Operations and Maintenance Managers, Supply Chain and Procurement Managers, Risk and Finance Managers, and IT and Sustainability Managers, who use an application for managing ESG reporting, assets and facilities, supply chain, climate risk, and IT sustainability infrastructure.

actors.name: Asset
actors.description: Assets can include machinery, equipment, buildings, vehicles, and other infrastructure that are necessary for the operation of a business or organization.

actors.name: Controls
actors.description: A control system uses sensors and actuators to monitor and control the operation of a system or process. Control systems can be used to automatically adjust the operation of a system based on predetermined setpoints, as well as to respond to changes in the environment or to commands from operators.

actors.name: IoT
actors.description: The Internet of Things (IoT) is a system of interconnected devices, machines, and systems communicating and exchanging data over a network without requiring human intervention. These devices may be connected through various technologies, including wireless, wired, and Bluetooth, and they can be used to gather and transmit data for various purposes, including energy management, building automation, and asset tracking.

actors.name: Lease Information
actors.description: A sensor is a device that provides a usable output in response to a specified physical input. Sensors are often used to detect and measure environmental parameters such as temperature, humidity, air quality, and occupancy.

actors.name: Lease System
actors.description: A lease system is a method of acquiring the use of an asset or property for a specific period in exchange for periodic payments, called rentals or leases.

actors.name: Metering System
actors.description: The metering system is a system of meters that provides data on energy use, energy demand, or other performance characteristics of a building system, subsystem, or equipment. Building Management

actors.name: Network equipment
actors.description: A sensor is a device that provides a usable output in response to a specified physical input. Sensors are often used to detect and measure environmental parameters such as temperature, humidity, air quality, and occupancy.

actors.name: Network Equipment
actors.description: Network equipment refers to the hardware and software that is used to connect devices and systems to a network, such as a local area network (LAN) or a wide area network (WAN). Network equipment includes devices such as routers, switches, hubs, and modems, as well as cables and other connectivity devices.

actors.name: Reporting System
actors.description: A reporting system provide users with the necessary information to make informed decisions and take action to improve the performance of the domain or function being monitored.

actors.name: Sensors
actors.description: A sensor is a device that provides a usable output in response to a specified physical input. Sensors are often used to detect and measure environmental parameters such as temperature, humidity, air quality, and occupancy.

actors.name: Spreadsheet
actors.description: A sensor is a device that provides a usable output in response to a specified physical input. Sensors are often used to detect and measure environmental parameters such as temperature, humidity, air quality, and occupancy.

actors.name: Spreadsheets
actors.description: A physical layer spreadsheet contains transactional and interval data of asset assets in the facility.

logicalComponents.name: Accelerate Decarbonization
logicalComponents.description: Accelerate decarbonization refers to the process of increasing the speed and scale at which carbon dioxide (CO2) and other greenhouse gases are reduced or eliminated in order to mitigate the impacts of climate change.

logicalComponents.name: Advancing Net Zero
logicalComponents.description: Advancing Net Zero is WorldGBC's global program working towards total sector decarbonization by 2050

logicalComponents.name: AI Assistant
logicalComponents.description: An AI assistant is a software application or system that is designed to perform tasks and provide assistance to users using artificial intelligence (AI) technologies, such as natural language processing (NLP) and machine learning.

logicalComponents.name: CDP
logicalComponents.description: CDP is a not-for-profit charity that runs the global disclosure system for investors, companies, cities, states and regions to manage their environmental impacts.

logicalComponents.name: Circular Economy&Reverse Logistics
logicalComponents.description: Circular economy is an economic model in which resources are conserved and waste is minimized through the reuse and recycling of materials and products. Reverse logistics is a set of processes and activities related to the management of the return or reuse of products, materials, and resources.

logicalComponents.name: Climate Risk Map
logicalComponents.description: A climate risk map is a visual representation of the potential risks and impacts of climate change on a particular region or area.

logicalComponents.name: Computer Vision
logicalComponents.description: Computer vision is a field of artificial intelligence (AI) that involves the development of algorithms and systems that can interpret and understand visual data, such as images and videos.

logicalComponents.name: Connector
logicalComponents.description: Connector refers to a device or software that allows different devices or systems to communicate and exchange data with each other. Connectors enable the interoperability of different devices and systems, allowing them to work together and share data over a network.

logicalComponents.name: Data Model
logicalComponents.description: A data model is a way of organizing and representing data in a computer system. It defines the structure and relationships between different data pieces and serves as a blueprint for how the data will be stored and accessed.

logicalComponents.name: Dow Jones Sustainability Index
logicalComponents.description: The Dow Jones Sustainability Index was a stock index focused on European companies with high environmental, social, and governance (ESG) scores.

logicalComponents.name: Edge
logicalComponents.description: The "edge devices" are responsible for collecting, processing, and transmitting data from the assets being monitored, often in real-time.

logicalComponents.name: Efficiency Finder
logicalComponents.description: Application to identify and analyze the efficiency of assets within an asset management system. This may include identifying opportunities for improving the performance or efficiency of the asset, as well as identifying potential problems or inefficiencies that could impact its performance.

logicalComponents.name: Environmental Data
logicalComponents.description: Environmental data refers to information that is collected about the natural environment and its various components, such as air, water, soil, plants, etc. This data can be collected using various methods, including field observations, remote sensing, and laboratory analysis, and it can be used to understand and monitor the health and functioning of the environment.

logicalComponents.name: ERP
logicalComponents.description: Enterprise resource planning (ERP) systems are software platforms that are designed to help organizations manage and integrate their business processes, such as finance, accounting, human resources, procurement, and supply chain management.

logicalComponents.name: ESG Reporting Frameworks
logicalComponents.description: ESG (environmental, social, and governance) reporting frameworks are guidelines or standards that organizations can use to report on their environmental, social, and governance performance, risks, and impacts.

logicalComponents.name: External Events
logicalComponents.description: External events refer to changes in the environment or external conditions that can impact the operation of systems. External events can include a wide range of factors, such as temperature, humidity, air quality, or other physical conditions; certain substances or materials; or the presence or movement of people or objects.

logicalComponents.name: Financials
logicalComponents.description: Financial include various metrics, such as revenue, profits, expenses, cash flow, assets, liabilities, and equity.

logicalComponents.name: Geospatial Analytics
logicalComponents.description: Geospatial analytics is the analysis of spatial data to understand and visualize patterns, trends, and relationships in a geographic context.

logicalComponents.name: GHG Protocol
logicalComponents.description: GHG Protocol establishes comprehensive global standardized frameworks to measure and manage greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions from private and public sector operations, value chains and mitigation actions.

logicalComponents.name: Green Leases
logicalComponents.description: Green leases are leases for commercial or residential properties that include provisions related to environmental sustainability and energy efficiency. These provisions may require the tenant or property owner to take certain actions to reduce their environmental impact, such as using energy-efficient appliances or implementing water conservation measures.

logicalComponents.name: Intelligent Maintenance
logicalComponents.description: Application for managing and maintaining assets that use data and analytics to predict when maintenance is needed. This approach is designed to optimize the maintenance schedule for an asset based on its actual condition, rather than following a predetermined schedule or reacting to failures.

logicalComponents.name: IT Optimization Services
logicalComponents.description: Maximize the efficiency and sustainability of an organization's I.T. infrastructure and operations.

logicalComponents.name: Locations
logicalComponents.description: Location refers to the physical location of devices, sensors, and other assets connected to the network.

logicalComponents.name: Machine Learning
logicalComponents.description: Machine learning is a subfield of artificial intelligence (AI) that involves the development of algorithms and models that can learn from and make predictions or decisions based on data.

logicalComponents.name: Model Catalog
logicalComponents.description: The model catalog is a collection of models that are used to represent and analyze different aspects of the system. A model is a simplified representation of a system or process that helps to understand and analyze it.

logicalComponents.name: NPi
logicalComponents.description: The Australian National Pollutant Inventory (NPI) is a database maintained by the Australian government that provides information on emissions and pollutants released into the air, water, and land by industrial facilities across Australia.

logicalComponents.name: Pattern Detection Rules
logicalComponents.description: Pattern detection rules are a set of guidelines or criteria that are used to identify and classify patterns in data.

logicalComponents.name: Prediction
logicalComponents.description: Prediction refers to the process of using data and algorithms to identify patterns and trends and to make forecasts or predictions about future outcomes.

logicalComponents.name: Processing Rules
logicalComponents.description: Processing rules in data systems refer to the set of instructions or algorithms that are used to manipulate and process data within the system. These rules can be used to perform a wide range of tasks, including data validation, transformation, aggregation, and analysis.

logicalComponents.name: RE 100
logicalComponents.description: RE100 is the global corporate renewable energy initiative bringing together hundreds of large and ambitious businesses committed to 100% renewable electricity.

logicalComponents.name: REST API
logicalComponents.description: REST API (short for Representational State Transfer Application Programming Interface) is a type of API that allows software applications to communicate with each other over the internet. REST APIs use a standard set of protocols and data formats to exchange information between applications, allowing them to communicate and share data in a consistent and predictable manner.

logicalComponents.name: SASB
logicalComponents.description: SASB Standards guide the disclosure of financially material sustainability information by companies to their investors.

logicalComponents.name: Science Based Targets
logicalComponents.description: The Science Based Targets initiative is a collaboration between the CDP, the United Nations Global Compact, World Resources Institute and the World Wide Fund for Nature. Since 2015 more than 1,000 companies have joined the initiative to set a science-based climate target

logicalComponents.name: Scope 1, 2 GHG Accounting + Reporting
logicalComponents.description: Scope 1, 2, and 3 GHG (greenhouse gas) emissions are categories used to classify and report the greenhouse gas emissions of an organization. Scope 1 emissions are direct emissions that are under the control of an organization, such as emissions from company-owned vehicles or equipment. Scope 2 emissions are indirect emissions that result from an organization's consumption of purchased electricity, steam, heating, or cooling.

logicalComponents.name: Scope 3 GHG Accounting + Reporting
logicalComponents.description: Scope 3 GHG (greenhouse gas) accounting and reporting refers to the measurement, accounting, and reporting of greenhouse gas emissions from sources that are not directly owned or controlled by an organization, but that are related to its activities.

logicalComponents.name: Scope 3 GHG Reporting & Performance
logicalComponents.description: Scope 3 GHG (greenhouse gas) reporting and performance refers to the measurement, reporting, and management of greenhouse gas emissions from sources that are not directly owned or controlled by an organization, but that are related to its activities.

logicalComponents.name: Storage
logicalComponents.description: Storage refers to the physical or virtual space where data is saved and stored for later use. Storage is an essential part of any data system, enabling it to retain and access data over time.

logicalComponents.name: Sustainability Computing
logicalComponents.description: Designing and implementing computer systems and applications that are environmentally sustainable and minimize their impact on the planet.

logicalComponents.name: Sustainability Program Tracking
logicalComponents.description: Sustainability program tracking is the process of monitoring and measuring the progress and performance of a sustainability program or initiative.

logicalComponents.name: Sustainable Health
logicalComponents.description: It is the ability of an asset to operate effectively and efficiently over a long period of time without incurring excessive costs or causing negative impacts on the environment.

logicalComponents.name: Sustainable Projects
logicalComponents.description: Sustainable projects aim to reduce environmental impacts, such as greenhouse gas emissions or resource consumption, or improve social and economic conditions by creating jobs or improving quality of life.

logicalComponents.name: Sustainable Sourcing & Procurement
logicalComponents.description: Sustainable sourcing and procurement refers to the processes and practices used to acquire goods and services in a way that is environmentally, socially, and economically responsible and sustainable over the long term.

logicalComponents.name: Sustainable Space
logicalComponents.description: Sustainable space refers to physical spaces, such as buildings, neighborhoods, or communities, that are designed and operated in a way that is environmentally, socially, and economically responsible and sustainable over the long term.

nodePlusImplementation.description: Circular economy is an economic model in which resources are conserved and waste is minimized through the reuse and recycling of materials and products. Reverse logistics is a set of processes and activities related to the management of the return or reuse of products, materials, and resources.

overview.content:
Sustainability Reference Architecture The sustainability reference architecture diagram will illustrate how various software applications supporting different business segments can work together to assist customers in achieving their ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) goals. The diagram depicts the various data sources that capture sustainability information critical for producing corporate sustainability reports and how these data sources are collected, assembled, analyzed, and reported.  These processes are essential for ensuring an enterprise operates to support the organization's sustainability goals. Furthermore, the reference architecture highlights the importance of these data sources for not only tracking and reporting but also for operationalizing ESG goals through the implementation of corrective actions powered by artificial intelligence applications. The image below illustrates the journey of sustainability operations. 


To achieve sustainable operations, companies need to embark on a journey that starts with a strategy and roadmap, with ESG data reporting being a critical aspect.

It all starts with developing a strategy and roadmap, and ESG data reporting is critical. IBM Consulting and business partners can help customers in this regard, while the Envizi application can assist with ESG reporting.

The journey will vary depending on the customer's current state, priorities, and goals. For example, the next step in the above journey map is intelligent asset and facility infrastructure, where IBM Maximo and TRIRIGA applications can help reduce scope 1 and 2 emissions.

The next step in the journey addresses scope 3 carbon emissions, which the IBM Supply chain intelligence suite application can help with.

Climate risk mitigation may be the next logical step depending on the type of industry.

The final step is to reduce emissions from I.T. systems using responsible computing and Green IT, where IBM products like Turbonomic, Z16, and IBM Cloud can play a role.

No matter what options customers choose, IBM has a solution that can help them achieve their sustainability goals. You can refer to the following external links to learn about IBM's sustainability offerings in these areas.

  1. Sustainability Strategy and Roadmap
  2. Intelligent assets & facilities infrastructure
  3. Sustainable supply chain & circularity
  4. Climate Risk Management
  5. Responsible computing & Green IT

Here, we are focused on Sustainability Architecture. For an overview of it, see section 5.1.2. It covers various systems within an enterprise essential for capturing, reporting, and operationalizing sustainability goals. We are developing a drilled-down version of the Sustainability Architecture, and you will find those in the following list. We will update these links to include additional architectures as and when it is available.
  1. ESG Data Reporting Reference Architecture
  2. Intelligent Asset Reference Architecture
  3. Intelligent Facility Reference Architecture
  4. Sustainable supply chain & circularity Reference Architecture
  5. Climate Risk Management Reference Architecture
  6. Responsible Computing & Green IT Reference Architecture
If you have any questions or comments, contact Ren Bostic at rbostic@us.ibm.com or Balaji Santhanakrishnan at bsanthana@us.ibm.com

businessChallenge.content:
Business Challenge: Achieving Carbon Emission Reduction Goals
Many businesses face the challenge of achieving rigorous carbon emission reduction goals to meet the demands of various stakeholders, regulators, and peers. However, they often struggle to achieve these goals using silo systems that do not share data, are difficult to integrate, and are expensive to operate. This lack of integration and data sharing makes it hard for businesses to track their progress and hinders their ability to achieve their carbon reduction targets. To address this challenge, businesses need a simple, user-friendly software solution to help operationalize their ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) goals, streamline their efforts to reduce emissions, and provide real-time visibility into their progress toward meeting their reduction targets.

functionalRequirements.name: Asset operations anomaly detection with actionable insight
functionalRequirements.description: Asset operations anomaly detection with actionable insight is a use case in which organizations implement advanced analytics tools to identify unusual behavior in asset performance and take corrective actions. These capabilities help improve asset efficiency, reduce downtime, and minimize the negative impact of asset operations on the environment.
functionalRequirements.impact: Minimize the environmental impact of asset operations

functionalRequirements.name: Climate risk mitigation recommendation with actionable insight
functionalRequirements.description: Provides actionable insights and recommendations to mitigate climate risks and improve sustainability performance for an organization.
functionalRequirements.impact: Reduce the negative impact on their operations and enhancing their overall sustainability performance.

functionalRequirements.name: ESG Goal setting and tracking
functionalRequirements.description: ESG Goal setting and tracking function help organizations to identify areas where they can improve sustainability performance, track progress toward their sustainability goals, and report on their achievements to stakeholders, investors, and regulators.
functionalRequirements.impact: It enables organizations to improve their sustainability performance, align with stakeholder expectations, and achieve long-term business success through sustainable practices.

functionalRequirements.name: Facility Space operations anomaly detection with actionable insight
functionalRequirements.description: Function provides real-time monitoring and analytics to identify anomalies in facility space usage and provide actionable insights to optimize occupancy and improve space efficiency.
functionalRequirements.impact: Optimize space utilization, reduce energy consumption and operating costs, and improve employee productivity and satisfaction.

functionalRequirements.name: IT operations anomaly detection with actionable insight
functionalRequirements.description: Use of A.I. & Analytics to identify and diagnose abnormal behavior in I.T. systems and provides actionable insights to help improve performance, reduce downtime, and optimize resource usage.
functionalRequirements.impact: Enable the organization to detect and respond to I.T. infrastructure issues quickly, reducing downtime and improving system performance while reducing energy consumption and minimizing environmental impact.

functionalRequirements.name: Tracking supplier sustainability performance and promoting sustainable sourcing
functionalRequirements.description: Monitor supplier sustainability practices, identify improvement areas, and incentivize suppliers to adopt sustainable practices to reduce environmental impact and promote social responsibility.
functionalRequirements.impact: Encourages suppliers to adopt sustainable practices, reduces environmental impact, and improves social responsibility.

architecturalDecisions.name: Hybrid Cloud or On-Premise Approach
architecturalDecisions.problemStatement: common issues: Skill set / resources, migration cost, security
architecturalDecisions.motivation:
To have a standardized architecture.
Cost reduction.
Lack of skills -> would lead to the use of managed services

alternatives.name: Hybrid Cloud - Managed Services
alternatives.bestApplied: Whenever there are not enough skilled resources in OpenShift etc etc

alternatives.name: On-Premise Solution
alternatives.bestApplied:
When there is a dedicated team of cloud resources to support the environment.
When there is an existing OpenShift installation and storage etc. ldap for authentication of users.

subSystems.name: Climate Risk
subSystems.description: The climate risk layer allows customers to identify, track, manage and mitigate climate-based risks [for example - temperature, humidity, precipitation, frost etc.]

containedLogicalComponents.name: Climate Risk Map
containedLogicalComponents.description: A climate risk map is a visual representation of the potential risks and impacts of climate change on a particular region or area.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Environmental Data
containedLogicalComponents.description: Environmental data refers to information that is collected about the natural environment and its various components, such as air, water, soil, plants, etc. This data can be collected using various methods, including field observations, remote sensing, and laboratory analysis, and it can be used to understand and monitor the health and functioning of the environment.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Geospatial Analytics
containedLogicalComponents.description: Geospatial analytics is the analysis of spatial data to understand and visualize patterns, trends, and relationships in a geographic context.

subSystems.name: Data
subSystems.description: The data layer will help to store, standardize and normalize data in a meaningful[example - relationship between data] way that sustainability applications can consume.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Data Model
containedLogicalComponents.description: A data model is a way of organizing and representing data in a computer system. It defines the structure and relationships between different data pieces and serves as a blueprint for how the data will be stored and accessed.

containedLogicalComponents.name: ERP
containedLogicalComponents.description: Enterprise resource planning (ERP) systems are software platforms that are designed to help organizations manage and integrate their business processes, such as finance, accounting, human resources, procurement, and supply chain management.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Model Catalog
containedLogicalComponents.description: The model catalog is a collection of models that are used to represent and analyze different aspects of the system. A model is a simplified representation of a system or process that helps to understand and analyze it.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Processing Rules
containedLogicalComponents.description: Processing rules in data systems refer to the set of instructions or algorithms that are used to manipulate and process data within the system. These rules can be used to perform a wide range of tasks, including data validation, transformation, aggregation, and analysis.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Storage
containedLogicalComponents.description: Storage refers to the physical or virtual space where data is saved and stored for later use. Storage is an essential part of any data system, enabling it to retain and access data over time.

subSystems.name: Facility Management
subSystems.description: The facility management layer allows customers to enable sustainability-centric facilities management through various facility life cycle [acquire, build, manage, utilize, maintain and dispose of].

containedLogicalComponents.name: Green Leases
containedLogicalComponents.description: Green leases are leases for commercial or residential properties that include provisions related to environmental sustainability and energy efficiency. These provisions may require the tenant or property owner to take certain actions to reduce their environmental impact, such as using energy-efficient appliances or implementing water conservation measures.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Sustainable Projects
containedLogicalComponents.description: Sustainable projects aim to reduce environmental impacts, such as greenhouse gas emissions or resource consumption, or improve social and economic conditions by creating jobs or improving quality of life.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Sustainable Space
containedLogicalComponents.description: Sustainable space refers to physical spaces, such as buildings, neighborhoods, or communities, that are designed and operated in a way that is environmentally, socially, and economically responsible and sustainable over the long term.

subSystems.name: Integration
subSystems.description: The integration layer is the first stage in consuming information from the physical layer and will provide the interface to data and/or functionality of one or more sustainability applications.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Connector
containedLogicalComponents.description: Connector refers to a device or software that allows different devices or systems to communicate and exchange data with each other. Connectors enable the interoperability of different devices and systems, allowing them to work together and share data over a network.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Edge
containedLogicalComponents.description: The "edge devices" are responsible for collecting, processing, and transmitting data from the assets being monitored, often in real-time.

containedLogicalComponents.name: External Events
containedLogicalComponents.description: External events refer to changes in the environment or external conditions that can impact the operation of systems. External events can include a wide range of factors, such as temperature, humidity, air quality, or other physical conditions; certain substances or materials; or the presence or movement of people or objects.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Financials
containedLogicalComponents.description: Financial include various metrics, such as revenue, profits, expenses, cash flow, assets, liabilities, and equity.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Locations
containedLogicalComponents.description: Location refers to the physical location of devices, sensors, and other assets connected to the network.

containedLogicalComponents.name: REST API
containedLogicalComponents.description: REST API (short for Representational State Transfer Application Programming Interface) is a type of API that allows software applications to communicate with each other over the internet. REST APIs use a standard set of protocols and data formats to exchange information between applications, allowing them to communicate and share data in a consistent and predictable manner.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Web forms
containedLogicalComponents.description: A web form is a user interface element on a website that allows users to input and submit data to the website.

subSystems.name: Physical
subSystems.description: The physical layer is the foundation system of the Sustainability architecture where the data gets generated and stored.

containedActors.name: Asset
containedActors.description: Assets can include machinery, equipment, buildings, vehicles, and other infrastructure that are necessary for the operation of a business or organization.

containedActors.name: Controls
containedActors.description: A control system uses sensors and actuators to monitor and control the operation of a system or process. Control systems can be used to automatically adjust the operation of a system based on predetermined setpoints, as well as to respond to changes in the environment or to commands from operators.

containedActors.name: IoT
containedActors.description: The Internet of Things (IoT) is a system of interconnected devices, machines, and systems communicating and exchanging data over a network without requiring human intervention. These devices may be connected through various technologies, including wireless, wired, and Bluetooth, and they can be used to gather and transmit data for various purposes, including energy management, building automation, and asset tracking.

containedActors.name: Lease System
containedActors.description: A lease system is a method of acquiring the use of an asset or property for a specific period in exchange for periodic payments, called rentals or leases.

containedActors.name: Metering System
containedActors.description: The metering system is a system of meters that provides data on energy use, energy demand, or other performance characteristics of a building system, subsystem, or equipment. Building Management

containedActors.name: Network Equipment
containedActors.description: Network equipment refers to the hardware and software that is used to connect devices and systems to a network, such as a local area network (LAN) or a wide area network (WAN). Network equipment includes devices such as routers, switches, hubs, and modems, as well as cables and other connectivity devices.

containedActors.name: Sensors
containedActors.description: A sensor is a device that provides a usable output in response to a specified physical input. Sensors are often used to detect and measure environmental parameters such as temperature, humidity, air quality, and occupancy.

containedActors.name: Spreadsheets
containedActors.description: A physical layer spreadsheet contains transactional and interval data of asset assets in the facility.

subSystems.name: Supply Chain Circularity
subSystems.description: The Supply Chain Circularity Layer allows customers to minimize the costs and amount of carbon emissions generated by supply chain activities

containedLogicalComponents.name: Circular Economy&Reverse Logistics
containedLogicalComponents.description: Circular economy is an economic model in which resources are conserved and waste is minimized through the reuse and recycling of materials and products. Reverse logistics is a set of processes and activities related to the management of the return or reuse of products, materials, and resources.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Scope 3 GHG Reporting & Performance
containedLogicalComponents.description: Scope 3 GHG (greenhouse gas) reporting and performance refers to the measurement, reporting, and management of greenhouse gas emissions from sources that are not directly owned or controlled by an organization, but that are related to its activities.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Sustainable Sourcing & Procurement
containedLogicalComponents.description: Sustainable sourcing and procurement refers to the processes and practices used to acquire goods and services in a way that is environmentally, socially, and economically responsible and sustainable over the long term.

subSystems.name: AI & Analytics
subSystems.description: The AI & Analytics layer allows customers to sift through their sustainability application data points and extract valuable insights.

containedLogicalComponents.name: AI Assistant
containedLogicalComponents.description: An AI assistant is a software application or system that is designed to perform tasks and provide assistance to users using artificial intelligence (AI) technologies, such as natural language processing (NLP) and machine learning.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Computer Vision
containedLogicalComponents.description: Computer vision is a field of artificial intelligence (AI) that involves the development of algorithms and systems that can interpret and understand visual data, such as images and videos.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Machine Learning
containedLogicalComponents.description: Machine learning is a subfield of artificial intelligence (AI) that involves the development of algorithms and models that can learn from and make predictions or decisions based on data.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Pattern Detection Rules
containedLogicalComponents.description: Pattern detection rules are a set of guidelines or criteria that are used to identify and classify patterns in data.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Prediction
containedLogicalComponents.description: Prediction refers to the process of using data and algorithms to identify patterns and trends and to make forecasts or predictions about future outcomes.

subSystems.name: ESG Framework
subSystems.description: The ESG Reporting Framework lets customers establish goals, and report on those goals to meet regulatory requirements including auditability. Also, it allows customers to get insights into where organizations can make changes to improve their sustainability posture.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Advancing Net Zero
containedLogicalComponents.description: Advancing Net Zero is WorldGBC's global program working towards total sector decarbonization by 2050

containedLogicalComponents.name: CDP
containedLogicalComponents.description: CDP is a not-for-profit charity that runs the global disclosure system for investors, companies, cities, states and regions to manage their environmental impacts.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Dow Jones Sustainability Index
containedLogicalComponents.description: The Dow Jones Sustainability Index was a stock index focused on European companies with high environmental, social, and governance (ESG) scores.

containedLogicalComponents.name: GHG Protocol
containedLogicalComponents.description: GHG Protocol establishes comprehensive global standardized frameworks to measure and manage greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions from private and public sector operations, value chains and mitigation actions.

containedLogicalComponents.name: NPi
containedLogicalComponents.description: The Australian National Pollutant Inventory (NPI) is a database maintained by the Australian government that provides information on emissions and pollutants released into the air, water, and land by industrial facilities across Australia.

containedLogicalComponents.name: RE 100
containedLogicalComponents.description: RE100 is the global corporate renewable energy initiative bringing together hundreds of large and ambitious businesses committed to 100% renewable electricity.

containedLogicalComponents.name: SASB
containedLogicalComponents.description: SASB Standards guide the disclosure of financially material sustainability information by companies to their investors.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Science Based Targets
containedLogicalComponents.description: The Science Based Targets initiative is a collaboration between the CDP, the United Nations Global Compact, World Resources Institute and the World Wide Fund for Nature. Since 2015 more than 1,000 companies have joined the initiative to set a science-based climate target

containedLogicalComponents.name: TCFD
containedLogicalComponents.description: TCFD reporting refers to the practice of reporting on climate-related financial risks and opportunities in accordance with the recommendations of the Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (

subSystems.name: ESG Reporting
subSystems.description: The ESG platform layer allows customers to get deep visibility into environmental, human, and governance risks.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Accelerate Decarbonization
containedLogicalComponents.description: Accelerate decarbonization refers to the process of increasing the speed and scale at which carbon dioxide (CO2) and other greenhouse gases are reduced or eliminated in order to mitigate the impacts of climate change.

containedLogicalComponents.name: ESG Reporting Frameworks
containedLogicalComponents.description: ESG (environmental, social, and governance) reporting frameworks are guidelines or standards that organizations can use to report on their environmental, social, and governance performance, risks, and impacts.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Scope 1, 2 GHG Accounting + Reporting
containedLogicalComponents.description: Scope 1, 2, and 3 GHG (greenhouse gas) emissions are categories used to classify and report the greenhouse gas emissions of an organization. Scope 1 emissions are direct emissions that are under the control of an organization, such as emissions from company-owned vehicles or equipment. Scope 2 emissions are indirect emissions that result from an organization's consumption of purchased electricity, steam, heating, or cooling.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Scope 3 GHG Accounting + Reporting
containedLogicalComponents.description: Scope 3 GHG (greenhouse gas) accounting and reporting refers to the measurement, accounting, and reporting of greenhouse gas emissions from sources that are not directly owned or controlled by an organization, but that are related to its activities.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Sustainability Program Tracking
containedLogicalComponents.description: Sustainability program tracking is the process of monitoring and measuring the progress and performance of a sustainability program or initiative.

subSystems.name: Responsible computing & Green IT
subSystems.description: The Supply Chain Circularity Layer allows customers to minimize the costs and amount of carbon emissions generated by supply chain activities

containedLogicalComponents.name: IT Optimization Services
containedLogicalComponents.description: Maximize the efficiency and sustainability of an organization's I.T. infrastructure and operations.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Sustainability Computing
containedLogicalComponents.description: Designing and implementing computer systems and applications that are environmentally sustainable and minimize their impact on the planet.

usageScenario.name: Managing an Asset

usageSteps.description: The integration allows seamless data transfer from physical and ERP systems within the client network to enterprise sustainability applications in hybrid cloud.
The data from physical and ERP systems are stored, analyzed, and consumed to achieve the ESG goals of an organization, thereby improving its environmental sustainability performance.
Intelligent maintenance application consumes the asset data to identify operational issues, improve maintenance and reduce environmental impact.
The information from asset management applications will be consumed by the ESG reporting engine for goal setting and tracking the ESG goals.

useCaseDiagram.name: Business Use Cases
useCaseDiagram.description: This shows the five key business use cases in Sustainability.

actors.name: Application Users
actors.description: Application users refer to individuals with different roles and responsibilities within an enterprise, such as Sustainability Managers, Operations and Maintenance Managers, Supply Chain and Procurement Managers, Risk and Finance Managers, and IT and Sustainability Managers, who use an application for managing ESG reporting, assets and facilities, supply chain, climate risk, and IT sustainability infrastructure.

useCases.name: Asset Operation Optimization for Sustainability
useCases.description: To identify and implement sustainable practices and initiatives that reduce the negative impact of assets on the environment while improving efficiency and performance.

useCases.name: Space Utilization Optimization for Sustainability
useCases.description: To analyze and optimize the usage of physical space in an organization to reduce waste, increase efficiency, and support sustainability goals.

useCases.name: Climate Risk Management for Sustainability
useCases.description: Identify, assess, and manage climate-related risks to an organization's operations, assets, and stakeholders through effective risk management strategies.

useCases.name: Supply Chain Optimization for Sustainability
useCases.description: Optimize supply chain operations to reduce environmental impact, increase efficiency, and promote sustainability in an organization's supply chain.

useCases.name: Green IT for Sustainability
useCases.description: Implement sustainable and environmentally-friendly practices and technologies in an organization's I.T. infrastructure to reduce energy consumption, carbon footprint, and promote sustainability.

properties.name: Storage
properties.description: Storage refers to the physical or virtual space where data is saved and stored for later use. Storage is an essential part of any data system, enabling it to retain and access data over time.

properties.name: Accelerate Decarbonization

properties.name: Sustainable Space
properties.description: Sustainable space refers to physical spaces, such as buildings, neighborhoods, or communities, that are designed and operated in a way that is environmentally, socially, and economically responsible and sustainable over the long term.

properties.name: Sustainable Health
properties.description: It is the ability of an asset to operate effectively and efficiently over a long period of time without incurring excessive costs or causing negative impacts on the environment.

properties.name: Scope 3 GHG Reporting & Performance
properties.description: Scope 3 GHG (greenhouse gas) reporting and performance refers to the measurement, reporting, and management of greenhouse gas emissions from sources that are not directly owned or controlled by an organization, but that are related to its activities.

properties.name: Efficiency Finder
properties.description: Application to identify and analyze the efficiency of assets within an asset management system. This may include identifying opportunities for improving the performance or efficiency of the asset, as well as identifying potential problems or inefficiencies that could impact its performance.

properties.name: Climate Risk Map
properties.description: A climate risk map is a visual representation of the potential risks and impacts of climate change on a particular region or area.

properties.name: Green Leases
properties.description: Green leases are leases for commercial or residential properties that include provisions related to environmental sustainability and energy efficiency. These provisions may require the tenant or property owner to take certain actions to reduce their environmental impact, such as using energy-efficient appliances or implementing water conservation measures.

properties.name: Integration and Connectivity Services
properties.description:
The integration services consumes information from the physical and ERP systems and will provide the interface to data and/or functionality of one or more sustainability applications.. This includes:
  • REST API
  • Connector
  • Web Forms
  • Edge
  • External Events
  • Financials
  • Locations
For more information, refer to the Sustainability Overview Reference Architecture.

properties.name: ERP
properties.description: data from erp will push to asset mgmt, facilities, and supply chain

properties.name: Facilities Management
properties.description: The facility management layer allows customers to enable sustainability-centric facilities management through various facility life cycle [acquire, build, manage, utilize, maintain and dispose of].

properties.name: ESG Reporting
properties.description: The ESG platform layer allows customers to get deep visibility into environmental, human, and governance risks.

properties.name: Intelligent Maintenance
properties.description: Application for managing and maintaining assets that use data and analytics to predict when maintenance is needed. This approach is designed to optimize the maintenance schedule for an asset based on its actual condition, rather than following a predetermined schedule or reacting to failures.

properties.name: Sustainable Projects
properties.description: Sustainable projects aim to reduce environmental impacts, such as greenhouse gas emissions or resource consumption, or improve social and economic conditions by creating jobs or improving quality of life.

properties.name: IT Optimization Services
properties.description: Maximize the efficiency and sustainability of an organization's I.T. infrastructure and operations.

properties.name: Sustainability Computing
properties.description: Designing and implementing computer systems and applications that are environmentally sustainable and minimize their impact on the planet.

properties.name: Climate Risk
properties.description: The climate risk layer allows customers to identify, track, manage and mitigate climate-based risks [for example - temperature, humidity, precipitation, frost etc.]

properties.name: Asset Management
properties.description: The asset management layer allows customers to enable sustainability centric planning, operation, and management of their complex physical assets.

properties.name: Supply Chain Circularity
properties.description: The Supply Chain Circularity Layer allows customers to minimize the costs and amount of carbon emissions generated by supply chain activities

properties.name: Physical Systems
properties.description:
The physical system is where the following data gets generated and stored. This includes:
  • Sensors
  • IoT
  • Metering System
  • Controls
  • Asset
  • Lease System
  • Network Equipment
  • Spreadsheets
For more information, refer to the Enterprise view: Sustainability Overview Reference Architecture.

properties.name: Geospatial Analytics
properties.description: Geospatial analytics is the analysis of spatial data to understand and visualize patterns, trends, and relationships in a geographic context.

properties.name: Sustainable Sourcing & Procurement
properties.description: Sustainable sourcing and procurement refers to the processes and practices used to acquire goods and services in a way that is environmentally, socially, and economically responsible and sustainable over the long term.

properties.name: Circular Economy & Reverse Logistics
properties.description: Circular economy is an economic model in which resources are conserved and waste is minimized through the reuse and recycling of materials and products. Reverse logistics is a set of processes and activities related to the management of the return or reuse of products, materials, and resources.

properties.name: Environmental Data
properties.description: Environmental data refers to information that is collected about the natural environment and its various components, such as air, water, soil, plants, etc. This data can be collected using various methods, including field observations, remote sensing, and laboratory analysis, and it can be used to understand and monitor the health and functioning of the environment.

properties.name: Supply Chain Optimization for Sustainability
properties.description: Optimize supply chain operations to reduce environmental impact, increase efficiency, and promote sustainability in an organization's supply chain.

properties.name: Asset Operation Optimization for Sustainability
properties.description: To identify and implement sustainable practices and initiatives that reduce the negative impact of assets on the environment while improving efficiency and performance.

properties.name: Climate Risk Management for Sustainability
properties.description: Identify, assess, and manage climate-related risks to an organization's operations, assets, and stakeholders through effective risk management strategies.

properties.name: Green IT for Sustainability
properties.description: Implement sustainable and environmentally-friendly practices and technologies in an organization's I.T. infrastructure to reduce energy consumption, carbon footprint, and promote sustainability.

properties.name: Space Utilization Optimization for Sustainability
properties.description: To analyze and optimize the usage of physical space in an organization to reduce waste, increase efficiency, and support sustainability goals.

properties.impact: Minimize the environmental impact of asset operations
properties.name: Asset operations anomaly detection with actionable insight
properties.description: Asset operations anomaly detection with actionable insight is a use case in which organizations implement advanced analytics tools to identify unusual behavior in asset performance and take corrective actions. These capabilities help improve asset efficiency, reduce downtime, and minimize the negative impact of asset operations on the environment.

properties.impact: Reduce the negative impact on their operations and enhancing their overall sustainability performance.
properties.name: Climate risk mitigation recommendation with actionable insight
properties.description: Provides actionable insights and recommendations to mitigate climate risks and improve sustainability performance for an organization.

properties.impact: Enable the organization to detect and respond to I.T. infrastructure issues quickly, reducing downtime and improving system performance while reducing energy consumption and minimizing environmental impact.
properties.name: IT operations anomaly detection with actionable insight
properties.description: Use of A.I. & Analytics to identify and diagnose abnormal behavior in I.T. systems and provides actionable insights to help improve performance, reduce downtime, and optimize resource usage.

properties.impact: Optimize space utilization, reduce energy consumption and operating costs, and improve employee productivity and satisfaction.
properties.name: Facility Space operations anomaly detection with actionable insight
properties.description: Function provides real-time monitoring and analytics to identify anomalies in facility space usage and provide actionable insights to optimize occupancy and improve space efficiency.

properties.impact: Encourages suppliers to adopt sustainable practices, reduces environmental impact, and improves social responsibility.
properties.name: Tracking supplier sustainability performance and promoting sustainable sourcing
properties.description: Monitor supplier sustainability practices, identify improvement areas, and incentivize suppliers to adopt sustainable practices to reduce environmental impact and promote social responsibility.

properties.impact: It enables organizations to improve their sustainability performance, align with stakeholder expectations, and achieve long-term business success through sustainable practices.
properties.name: ESG Goal setting and tracking
properties.description: ESG Goal setting and tracking function help organizations to identify areas where they can improve sustainability performance, track progress toward their sustainability goals, and report on their achievements to stakeholders, investors, and regulators.
